meta.curation_policy: Curated entries aligned with university-level drawing/animation instruction; each entry includes at least one canonical book reference.

sources: Edwards, B. — Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain
Nicolaïdes, K. — The Natural Way to Draw
Speed, H. — The Practice and Science of Drawing
Ruskin, J. — The Elements of Drawing
Mayer, R. — The Artist’s Handbook of Materials and Techniques
Robertson, S. — How to Draw (and/or How to Render)
Williams, R. — The Animator’s Survival Kit

techniques.name: Contour drawing
techniques.definition: Drawing the outlines and edges of a subject to train observation and hand–eye coordination.
references: Nicolaïdes — The Natural Way to Draw
Edwards — Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain

techniques.name: Blind contour
techniques.definition: Contour drawing without looking at the paper; strengthens perception and reduces reliance on visual symbols.
tips: Do not 'peek' to correct—accept distortion as part of training
references: Edwards — Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain
Nicolaïdes — The Natural Way to Draw

techniques.name: Gesture drawing
techniques.definition: Capturing the overall action, rhythm, and line-of-action of a pose with minimal marks.
tips: Start with the line of action
Favor movement and weight over details
references: Nicolaïdes — The Natural Way to Draw

techniques.name: Negative space drawing
techniques.definition: Drawing the shapes around an object to improve accuracy and reduce symbolic shortcuts.
references: Edwards — Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain

techniques.name: Sight-size measurement
techniques.definition: Measuring proportions by holding a constant viewing position and comparing lengths/angles visually.
tips: Use a pencil at arm’s length as a measuring tool
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

techniques.name: Comparative measurement
techniques.definition: Measuring relative sizes and angles by comparing one feature against another feature as a unit.
tips: Check angles with plumb lines and alignment
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

techniques.name: Cross-hatching
techniques.definition: Building tone and form with overlapping sets of parallel lines at different angles.
tips: Keep spacing consistent for clean values
Follow form direction to enhance volume
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

techniques.name: Hatching
techniques.definition: Creating tone with a single-direction set of parallel strokes.
tips: Use line density rather than pressure to control value

techniques.name: Stippling
techniques.definition: Creating values via dot density rather than lines.
tips: Avoid clustering that creates unintended patterns
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

techniques.name: Tonal blocking
techniques.definition: Separating large value masses (light/mid/shadow) before adding detail.
tips: Keep edges simple until structure is correct
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

techniques.name: Edge control
techniques.definition: Deliberately varying hard, soft, and lost edges to guide focus and describe form.
tips: Hard edges attract attention; use sparingly

techniques.name: Construction drawing
techniques.definition: Building complex forms from simple primitives (box, cylinder, sphere) to maintain solidity.
tips: Align ellipses to the form’s axis

techniques.name: Form intersections
techniques.definition: Using overlaps and intersections of primitives to understand spatial relationships and volume.
tips: Use consistent perspective rules across all primitives

techniques.name: Box rotation drill
techniques.definition: Rotating boxes in space to internalize perspective convergence and foreshortening.

techniques.name: Ellipses in perspective
techniques.definition: Drawing ellipses that correctly represent circles in perspective.
tips: Align ellipse minor axis to cylinder axis

techniques.name: Value scales
techniques.definition: Practicing consistent stepped values to improve tonal control.
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

techniques.name: Material rendering study
techniques.definition: Isolating a material (metal, glass, fabric) and analyzing its value patterns and edges.
tips: Use edge quality to sell surface properties

techniques.name: Atmospheric perspective
techniques.definition: Suggesting depth by reducing contrast and detail with distance.
tips: Lower contrast and saturation in distant forms
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

techniques.name: Thumbnail composition
techniques.definition: Small, fast sketches to explore value grouping, balance, and focal hierarchy.
tips: Keep it small to avoid detail
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

tools.name: Graphite pencil (HB)
tools.description: Mid-range hardness for general sketching and construction lines.
notes: Reliable baseline pencil; pairs well with kneaded eraser

tools.name: Graphite pencil (2B)
tools.description: Softer graphite for darker values and expressive line.
notes: Smudges more easily; manage with clean hand placement

tools.name: Mechanical pencil (0.5mm)
tools.description: Consistent line width suited to precise construction and measured drawing.

tools.name: Kneaded eraser
tools.description: Malleable eraser that lifts graphite/charcoal gradually without harsh marks.
notes: Clean by kneading; do not rub aggressively

tools.name: Vinyl/Plastic eraser
tools.description: Harder eraser for strong removal of graphite.
notes: Can damage paper if overused; use light pressure

tools.name: Charcoal (vine)
tools.description: Light, easily erasable charcoal ideal for broad gesture and massing.

tools.name: Charcoal (compressed)
tools.description: Darker, denser charcoal with higher value range; harder to erase fully.
notes: Use with blending tools cautiously to avoid muddy values

tools.name: Conte crayon
tools.description: Waxier dry medium; produces crisp lines and stable darks.
notes: Good for controlled hatching and edge work

tools.name: Blending stump (tortillon)
tools.description: Paper tool used to blend dry media and soften transitions.
notes: Blend sparingly; preserve value structure and edges

tools.name: India ink (black)
tools.description: Permanent black ink for high-contrast linework and washes.
notes: Test on paper; once permanent, corrections are limited

tools.name: Dip pen + nib
tools.description: Pen system offering variable line weight with pressure/angle changes.
notes: Clean nibs regularly to maintain flow

tools.name: Newsprint pad
tools.description: Low-cost paper suited to gesture and warm-up drills.
notes: Not archival; do not expect long-term preservation
references: Nicolaïdes — The Natural Way to Draw

tools.name: Drawing paper (acid-free)
tools.description: More durable paper suitable for finished studies and layering.
notes: Choose tooth based on medium (graphite vs charcoal)

tools.name: Fixative (workable)
tools.description: Spray used to set dry media layers while allowing additional drawing.
notes: Use in ventilated areas; apply light coats

animation_concepts.name: Line of action
animation_concepts.definition: A simplified directional line capturing the main energy and movement of a pose.

animation_concepts.name: Keyframe
animation_concepts.definition: A defining drawing that marks a significant pose or timing point in an action.

animation_concepts.name: In-between
animation_concepts.definition: Intermediate drawings that create smooth motion between keyframes.

animation_concepts.name: Timing and spacing
animation_concepts.definition: Timing is how long an action takes; spacing is how far the object moves between frames.
tips: Close spacing slows motion; wide spacing speeds it up

animation_concepts.name: Squash and stretch
animation_concepts.definition: Deforming forms to show weight, flexibility, and impact while preserving volume.

animation_concepts.name: Anticipation
animation_concepts.definition: A preparatory action that sets up and clarifies the main action.
tips: Make anticipation smaller than the main action
Use it to direct viewer attention

animation_concepts.name: Arcs
animation_concepts.definition: Natural motion tends to travel in arcs rather than straight lines.

academic_topics.name: Proportion and alignment
academic_topics.summary: A set of observational methods (plumb lines, comparative measurement) to maintain accurate relationships.
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

academic_topics.name: Value grouping
academic_topics.summary: Simplifying values into clear groups to improve readability and light logic.
references: Speed — The Practice and Science of Drawing

academic_topics.name: Perspective fundamentals
academic_topics.summary: Horizon, vanishing points, and convergence as the basis for spatial illusion.
drills: Interior thumbnails with a fixed horizon
